column4: I was having problems running thunderbird. It seems to run normally without error (even from the command line), but when I start it up, I get the popup for my new messages, but the app never appears in the command line or on my screen. Could it be dumping errors to a log file somewhere? How do I debug this?
try starting thunderbird from the terminal, with : thunderbird &
You will get any error messages or warnings straight to your terminal that way.
if you would like to browse them afterwards, just type: thunderbird 2>thunderbird.error &
that will give you all the errors and warnings in that file.
I do that and still get no errors though
It just seems to vanish
and ps -e returns two processes: thunderbird and thunderbird-bin
maybe there is a cmd-line parameter that shows more warnings than normal. There is bound to be a thunderbird channel right here on Freenode that might give you more specific info
yea, I was just wondering if there was some general system log that it might be dumping errors to
normally it should dump any errors to standard_error that gets redirected to the file with 2>thunderbird.error
yea, I know that much. I just had read something about a System Message log a while back. Wondering if maybe that might help
there is no official thunderbird channel on Freenode. There is a mozilla channel, though.
strike that, mozilla seems to be an alias for firefox# (...Sigh...)
try running thunderbird in safe-mode, like so: thunderbird -safe-mode &
Hrmm, maybe it's displaying to the wrong X Session? How do I get the label for my current session?
cause even in safe mode, it launches, process is listed, but it's not displayed anywhere
try removing thunderbird and reinstalling through the package manager, like sudo apt-get remove thunderbird && sudo ap-get install thunderbird
this won't effect your e-mail, it will just reinstall your thunderbird
thanks, trying it out
most of the times, reinstalling is much faster than tinkering with all kinds of settings ;-)
I ended up just erasing my .mozilla-thunderbird folder and it seems to have done the trick (didn't have much set up except my gmail imap)
Maybe I'll uninstall and re-install too.
In that case some of your settings of your previous install went haywire. Glad to hear that everything is running properly again :-D
